text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen today we're 
making one of the most popular dim sum dishes ever

they're these little dumplings commonly known as 
shumai or siu mai in Chinese but in Thai they are

called kanom jeeb now kanom is snack and 
jeeb means pleats and it's referring to the

little pleats that form on the wrapper around the 
dumplings now even though this is a Chinese dish

originally it's so popular in Thailand now and 
when we make them we add our own little flair and

flavor to them so let's get started all right 
so in Thailand kinome deep are always either

pork shrimp or crab depending on how much money 
you've got to spend so today we're gonna make a

shrimp version however if we make a shrimp or 
a crab version there's always a little bit of

pork mixed into it as well because pork does add 
a nice flavor and the fat helps with the texture

in general so what I've got here is some ground 
pork and also some shrimp meat which I'm going to

grind up in a little bit they don't sell ground 
shrimp unfortunately and I've also got a little

extra shrimp here that I have cut up into small 
pieces this is my own little trick because then

you get little chunks of shrimp as you chew and 
it also looks nicer so I am going to grind the

shrimp in my food processor alright that looks 
good just so there are no big chunks it doesn't

need to be a complete puree by the way a little 
cleanup trick for you if you've got pure aged

shrimp or ground pork or whatever stuck in your 
food processor don't wash it with hot water Kait

rinse it off first with cold water if you wash 
it with hot water it'll cook the meat and then

it's really stuck to it but if you rinse it 
first with cold water it'll come off really

easily I've learned that the hard way okay I'm 
just gonna put the ground pork in here so here's

the hardware it gets a little Thai I'm gonna 
add some garlic and white peppercorns and pound

that into a paste and you may notice by now that 
whenever I deal with sort of ground meat mixture

garlic and white peppercorns are always in it so 
I'm just getting that to be really really fine

okay so now it's really really fine I'm gonna 
add that to my pork and shrimp mixture this is

where rubber spatula really comes in handy okay 
you don't want to waste any of that flavor so

the seasoning is really simple I've got some soy 
sauce here and I'm using Thai soy sauce but you

can use whatever soy sauce you have and also some 
fish sauce I love fish sauce it's you my and this

is I guess the part where it really gets Thai a 
little bit of sesame oil toasted sesame oil and

this is the Chinese part we don't use sesame oil 
much in Thai cuisine and when we do with usually a

Chinese influence a little bit of sugar just to 
balance out the saltiness I like to add an egg

now some recipes don't call for an egg some do 
I just find that if you do then you get a more

you know tender dumpling at the end cornstarch 
and the cornstarch is just gonna help absorb the

liquid that is in there to make sure it's not too 
runny and also I think it helps with the texture

once again a little a little sort of bounciness 
I'm gonna mash all this up and I'm gonna do it

with my hands so I'm gonna get some gloves on 
get really you're ready for this and it's gonna

look really runny at first don't worry it will 
thicken up all right see how much firmer it is

now where it was really soupy before where now you 
can actually it'll actually hold its shape so I'm

just gonna keep going a little bit more I know it 
can get even stickier it's sort of like kneading

bread dough I feel like there's something going on 
where the more you work it the thicker it becomes

alright that looks good to me it's nice and sticky 
and smooth so now I'm going to add all the stuff

that I don't want to mash let's chunkier stuff 
so the shrimp meat that we were talking about

before and also I'm going to add some diced jicama 
now this is something that's very commonly done

in Thailand and jicama if you are familiar with 
what that is it's a root vegetable and I've got

to have a one to show you here so if it were 
hole it would look kind of like this it's got

a texture very similar to daikon it's crunchy and 
juicy sort of like apples or radishes it may have

started out as some a way to bulk up so you know 
suits cheaper you don't have to put as much pork

this is great in salads by the way you cut them 
up into little sticks really crunchy refreshing

stuff so that's getting added in I'm also gonna 
add some green onions I believe that is it and

now I'm just gonna give this a stir and I actually 
like to add jicama because it helps almost lighten

the texture of it because if it's all meat then 
it can be quite heavy but when you've got some

vegetables in there then it's not so heavy then 
you can eat more of them all right time to wrap

my least favorite part of this whole process but 
that's okay it goes faster than skewering okay so

I'm using wonton wrappers but I'm going to cut 
the corners off a little bit because otherwise

there's they're just gonna stick up if you can 
get round ones those will work better before I

wrap it want to make sure I have my steamer rack 
ready so I can put them directly on the rack I'm

going to line it with banana leaf for two reasons 
one if I put them directly on the rack it'll stick

so if you're not gonna line it with banana 
leaf make sure you all the rack and two when

banana leaves are steamed with the dumplings they 
infuse a really nice subtle force the aroma into

the dumplings which I love so you know you don't 
have to but if you've got some laying around and

they freeze really well so I'm gonna show you 
how I do it but see what feels comfortable for

you you don't have to do it exactly how I do it 
took me a few different ways to figure out what's

the best thing to do okay so I'm gonna take about 
a tablespoon of this mixture you can make this as

big or small as you like it doesn't matter and 
then I put it in my other hand and just close it

up like that flatten this part a bit and there 
you go and then you get these little pleats or

a little deep which is what kind of deep is all 
about now before I steam these I'm gonna garnish

them with what's classic garnishing Pilon and that 
is little carrot brunoise so they're like little

jewels of carrots that make for really pretty 
topping okay so these are going to steam over

boiling water for ten minutes and that's it and 
then they're ready to go so while that's steaming

let's quickly make the dipping sauce because you 
want to make sure the dipping sauce is done before

those come out because you want to serve them 
right away Kate so usually see you Meyer kinome

fever surf with sort of a vinegary soy sauce so 
you can buy VIN it like dim sum vinegar already

made but it's really really easy to make with 
things that you probably already have so I could

hear some chopped chilies because after all this 
is a Thai version and all our different sauces

always have some chilies and then I've got some 
soy sauce going in and this is Thai soy sauce

it's a little lighter than most other kinds of 
soy sauces so I am also gonna add some black

soy sauce or dark soy sauce just to bump bump 
up the colour and the richness a little bit and

of course the vinegar and I'm just using white 
vinegar nothing fancy here just to balance the

salt in the acidity as always just a little bit of 
sugar to mellow it all out and that's it back that

is the easiest dipping sauce ever you want to 
give it a stir make sure the sugar is dissolved

and give the chewy some time to some infuse into 
the rest of it and this will last a very long time

you keep it in the fridge super super yummy tada 
ooh and they're gonna be super puffed up so make

sure when you put them on they're not all stuck 
together okay cuz they will expand a little bit

so I'm gonna bring this over okay so now because 
these dry out really really quickly what I like

to do is brush them as soon as they're done with a 
little bit of garlic oil now this is something we

always always in Thailand serve with our condoms 
deep and that is fried garlic and this is the oil

the garlic was fried and so super garlicky oil I 
use garlic oil all the time so you know there's

nothing no for you but um I forgot my brush so I 
figured I can use the root of my green onions as

a natural brush instead you know be creative okay 
so just a little brushing on top and you can quite

generous with the oil cuz trust me that garlicky 
stuff is really good okay I'm gonna sprinkle this

with the crispy garlic here we go a little dipping 
sauce on there I have to say I have a favorite dim

sum place in Vancouver and this is better than 
theirs it's true maybe it's just because I'm Thai

so this is the flavour I really like I love that 
garlic enos from the garlic inside and outside

that little spiciness from the dipping sauce and 
the white pepper it's just enough to balance out

some of the richness of it but it's not it's not 
dead it looks like it should be really dense and

filling but because there's so much that jicama in 
there it's not as heavy as you might think it is

so you can really gonna go crazy on these things 
in the vinegar and the dipping sauce is the must

happen don't skip the dipping sauce though this 
is so good so the recipe as always of young hot

Thai kitchen calm when you make it send me a 
photo on Facebook Twitter or Instagram and if

you haven't subscribe to the show you can do so

I'll see you next time for your next finish is

gonna do it with my hands because what I want 
to do is make sure that the pork getting rich
